turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: I was wondering if you'd finished considering?

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Considering what?

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: What I asked you earlier?

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Poppy, please --

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: If you loved me like I loved you?

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Poppy, this is not the time!

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Did you feel that?

turns.speaker: POPPY
turns.text: Did I?  I've been waiting for that for years.

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Not that.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Okay.  Alright.  Okey-dokey.  Now, we need the nanobot.  The nanobot that initiated the reaction.  Once we have that we can stabilize the meltdown.  Simple really.  No problem.

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: The nanobot is gone.

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: The fact is, that the milk has been spilled and now we need you to tell us how to clean it up.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Cleaned up?  It can't be cleaned up! Without the nanobot the waste can't be stabilized!  That's what we've been trying to tell you!  The only thing we can do is run!  Run!  Run!

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Facts, Dr. Nebbleman.  Facts. You've been using cryogenics to control the waste from the mouse experiment, haven't you?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Well, yes.  The replicators are not as active at low temperatures.

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Then perhaps we can use liquid nitrogen to keep the meltdown under control.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: That might work.

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Poppy, order the trucks from the Gary plant.  And we're going to need a containment crew.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Well, at this time, I mean that is to say, it is difficult to project --

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Look, John, nobody wants to find out what happens.  That's why you're here.  We need your help on this one and that's why that suitcase is here.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: She could have given him something to stimulate his kidneys.

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Dr. Nebbleman, take care of them.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Where did he go?

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: The trunk.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: They're here!  They're here!  We have the nanobot.

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Excellent.  How long until the assembler tank is complete?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Dr. Makeo is working on it now, sir. I estimate at least another six hours.

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: In the meantime, why don't you find something useful for Dr. Bright to do.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Of course you understand, Dr. Argon, that once the nanobot is inside of you, there is no going back --

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Shut up and do it!

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Excellent work, Dr. Nebbleman.  You have outdone yourself.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: It'll be better for us if he simply disappears.  The gardener will know what to do.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Wait, wait, can I at least have his body?

turns.speaker: ARGON
turns.text: Donated to science.  Perfect.

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: Hey!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You don't want this.

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: Yeah, I do!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You have no idea what this is doing to your body.

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: I like Trix!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Here, kid, this is great stuff.  Why don't you give it a try?

turns.speaker: KID
turns.text: I want Trix!  Mommy!

turns.speaker: LITTERBUG
turns.text: Yeah?  So what?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: So what?  So what?  For starters, how about littering is a crime.

turns.speaker: LITTERBUG
turns.text: Haw-haw!  Why don't you run off and find a cop and I'll wait right here.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Why don't you just put this in your pocket so when you see a garbage can you can put it where it belongs.

turns.speaker: LITTERBUG
turns.text: Why don't you just shove it up your ass!  Haw-haw!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What is it with you litterbugs?  Is it a territorial thing, marking your turf with your garbage?

turns.speaker: LITTERBUG
turns.text: You better quit pushing me, pal.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I just want to know what goes on in the mind of a litterbug.  What chemical is secreted by your smooth brain that tells you, 'It's okay, just chuck it'?

turns.speaker: LITTERBUG
turns.text: Look, asshole, I don't got time for this.  If you got a problem, you better take care of it yourself.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Oh no, no, no.  No can do.  You enjoyed a tasty beverage and thus this receptacle becomes your responsibility and I don't care if it's a Styrofoam cup or the Exxon Valdez!  You've got to learn to take responsibility!

turns.speaker: LITTERBUG
turns.text: What are you going to do?  Make me throw it out?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I'll do whatever I have to do.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What?  Oh, I'm sorry, Nigel.  I was just thinking...

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Aaabout...?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: This morning.  I saw someone I haven't seen in a long time.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: A man?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yeah.  I knew him when I was still in school.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: What did he want?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'm not sure.  That's the funny thing about him.  He's the kind of guy that you never know what he wants or what he might do to get it.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Do you remember about five years ago, that uh... incident at Purnell Labs?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Oh yeah.  They were working on molecular assemblers, too, weren't they?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: They also tried using viral R.N.A. as the bonding element.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: That's right.  C.D.C. found out and closed them down...

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Yeah, somebody broke in and stole the samples, one of those animal rights groups, right?  I remember now, they freed all the monkeys which caused that huge pileup on the Massachusetts Turnpike, right?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yeah.  But it wasn't a group.  It was one man.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: That's the guy?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: What did security say?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: They'll in validate the key. Probably nothing.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Well, you got another problem.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The replicators?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Worse.  Mrs. Argon wants to talk to you.  She's waiting in the lab.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: This day just keeps going from bad to worse.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: I bet he hasn't read a single report we've written on the waste problem.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I hope you're right.  I'd feel a lot worse if he had read them and just didn't care.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What I've always done.  As long as I'm the only one who can build the nanobot, I'm the only one who can say when it should be tested.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You were never invited to my house.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: You're looking for a urine sample.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Of course, sir.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Dr. Argon, I know you want to use the nanobot on yourself, but you mustn't.  The situation is critical right now.  The replicators are growing exponentially.  If we wait much longer it will be too late. You have to use the nanobot to stop the meltdown.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I don't believe this is happening...

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Susan, Dr. Argon is giving you an opportunity here.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Opportunity?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: There's a guard outside my door! I'm a prisoner, Nigel!  Do you understand that?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Dr. Argon would say we are all prisoners.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Argon is a lunatic!  I can't believe I was stupid enough to believe I could control him.  You heard what he said, Nigel.  He doesn't care if all of Calumet City is turned to Jell-O.  How can that not affect you?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Because I am a new man, Susan.  I am a man of vision.  Your problem, Susan, is that you're always looking down.  If you'd just look up you'd see the big picture and in the big picture men of vision do not dwell on what might be lost.  They focus on what can be gained.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Is that what Argon told you?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: No!  Well, not those exact words.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Nigel, can't you see he's using you?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Of course he is, but at least there isn't a security guard outside my door.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You're afraid of him.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Who isn't?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: I'm a scientist.  I have lived my whole life by the diagnostic application of fact and the fact is, Argon is going to get whatever he wants, so if I were you, I'd give it to him.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You mean the designs for the nanobot?  You think after this I'm going to give them to him?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: I think that either you're going to give them to him or he's going to make you give them to him.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Make me?  How?  You think he's going to torture me?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: It's Sim.  We're almost there.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Mr. Sim, watch out!  O'Brien escaped and could be on his way!

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: You want to tell me what I'm looking for?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: I've only been invited to her house once, but I know there is a basement lab that she uses for private research.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: What's it smell like?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Smell?  Uh, something like methylcyanoacrylate.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Like Crazy Glue?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Yes.  That's it.  He's got it.  Oh God, he's got it!

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Sir, please try to hold still.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: So, I guess it worked.

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: He's probably right, sir, the building is probably going to collapse under its own weight.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: And if we evacuate, what do you want to do with O'Brien?

turns.speaker: NEBBLEMAN
turns.text: Susan!

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Wellie well, Dr. Bright.  You're just in time.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Daniel...

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What?  No kiss?  Not even for old times sake?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: When did you...?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Been out for six months now.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Really?  What have you been doing?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You know, this and that.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Somebody has to.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Same old Daniel.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Oh no.  Not by a long shot.  I may look like the old Daniel O'Brien, but on the inside, nothing is the same.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Is that so?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Oh yeah.  See, Susie, a man doesn't do the hard time and just pick up where he left off.  Oh no.  The big house does things to a man.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The big house?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: The big house.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Jesus, Daniel.  It wasn't Ryker's Island.  It was work camp for white collar criminals.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: A cage by any other name would still smell like sweaty ugly men.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I've been thinking about you a lot all these years, locked up in my cell.  I'd tear through every issue of the Midwest Science Journal looking for your latest findings, watching as you slowly worked your polymerization experiments up through single celled organisms to that holiest of holies, the fruit fly.  Exciting stuff.  I got to tell you, it really kept me going.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I guess I should be flattered.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I remember you said, nanotechnology was going to change the world.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It already is.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I've read they're using it to repair cancer cells.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: And for cleaning up oil spills.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Right.  You predicted it.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Do you ever wonder what happened to us, Susie?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It was a long time ago, Daniel.  We were young, different people, heading in different directions. That's all.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Well, it was good to see you, Daniel, but I have to be going.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Sure.  Can I ask you one more thing? You haven't published anything in a while.  How come?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Nothing really worthwhile.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: That's what I thought.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: And what I love about molecular science is the way it revolutionizes how we have to think.  It unifies the entire world on a single level. Everything is completely connected. Sometimes I can really feel it, everything around us, just a small part of a whole.  It's really wonderful.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Yeah, we'll see.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: We'll see?  What does that mean?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: We'll see how wonderful it is after you spend the next twenty years making Agent Orange.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: God, Daniel, I'm not going to make Agent Orange.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You think the chemists that invented Agent Orange twenty years ago were in school saying, 'Boy, I really got some good ideas for a highly toxic incendiary defoliant.'  You think Oppenheimer was dreaming about mushroom clouds before the war?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: We've had this conversation already, Daniel.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: All I'm saying is that the companies that have money for the kind of research you're interested in, have money because that's what they're interested in!  Money!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'm sorry I brought the whole thing up!  If you're gonna flip your wig --

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I can't help it, Suze.  It's this place.  You know how I get in these stores.  They freak me out.  All these tiny boxes, little cans filled with eight syllable God knows what.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You think it's a coincidence that they have all these aisles lined up like this, like a little maze! We're all lab rats running through their maze, pulling lever A or lever B, each designed to create some kind of bio-chemical dependency.  All the while they're everywhere, watching us, two-way mirrors, surveillance cameras, nodding to each other, making little notes.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You're insane.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Am I?  Look!  Right there!  That's exactly what I am talking about.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Daniel, give him the Trix.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Susan, this is the future of America here.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Susie!  You gotta help me!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Daniel, what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Please, Susan!  I need help! Something is wrong with me!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Sorry, Daniel, I'm a physicist, not a psychiatrist.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: No, something is really wrong... look!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: They did it to me!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The nanobot.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: ... just like the mouse.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Mouse?  What mouse?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: My first organic-polymerization was a lab mouse.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What happened to it?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You don't know?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It escaped from the lab before we could finish the experiment.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: But you've polymerized single-celled bacteria and the fruit flies, I know you have.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Then you must have at some point tried to reverse the procedure.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Oh no, no, no!  You've got to be able to fix me!  Please, Susan, tell me you can make me normal again!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Once the subject was polymerized we were unable to reassemble the original organic structure.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Oh God, please!  This can't be happening!  I can't be plastic!  A plastic man?!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Daniel!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I'm a plastic man!  A plastic man!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: We don't have time for hysterics.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: We don't?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What has happened to you is nothing compared to what is going to happen to Calumet City if we don't hurry.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What are these?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Mostly caffeine diuretics.  Help you go to the bathroom.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The nanobot is still inside you. It's programmed to exit through the urinary tract.  We need it as soon as possible, so swallow those.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Pills... you know how I feel about pills.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: If you don't want to do it this way, I can remove it surgically.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Why do we need it?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The nanobot is the only thing that can stabilize the waste.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What waste?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: To put is simply, the nanobot inside you is a microscopic machine encoded with information like a strand of messenger R.N.A. that is programmed to synthesize your molecules with the polyisoprenes of the assembler fluid, rebuilding your entire organic system on a molecular level.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: That was 'simple'?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The nanobot combined your molecules with the plastic molecules in the white assembler fluid, so that on a molecular level you now have more in common with a Good Year tire than a human being.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Got it.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The problem is the by-product created by the process.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: The waste.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The replicators start off like assemblers, but the replicators never stabilize.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What happens?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: That was an egg?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Three days ago it was.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What do these replicators do to people?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: With enough exposure, the same thing they do to everything else.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: So right now there's little replicators spreading throughout Argon's lab?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Isn't it already too late then?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I think while we're waiting, we had better run some basic diagnostics on you.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You're the doctor.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Lungs sound fine.  You didn't have any pre-existing physical conditions, did you?  Allergies? Infections?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: No, why?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Is something wrong?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: No, no, I just feel wired!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Susan!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What?  What's wrong?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Look at this!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What about it!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Just look at it!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The polymerization probably synthesized into a kind of methyl- cyanoacrylate.  So what's wrong?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Oh yeah, real funny.  Yuk-yuk. Let's laugh at everything a man believes in.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'm sorry, Daniel, but you have to admit it's pretty ironic that you of all people would be the first man ever polymerized.  It's got to mean something.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Means?  Oh no.  We won't know what it means until the end of the story and maybe then it won't seem quite as funny to you, Doctor Frankenstein!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What's that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Just giving credit where credit is due.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You have no one to blame but yourself.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Blame the victim.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Victim my ass!  You stole my security key and used it to break into my lab to do who knows what kind of damage!  Maybe this is the end of the story and you finally got what you deserved!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: This is what I deserve for trying to protect the world from a madman and his mercenary physicists?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You're not protecting the world, you're obstructing progress!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I don't consider uncontrollable toxic waste progress!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: And I'm sure you thought Columbus was going to sail off the edge of the world!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: But lo and behold he found another world that progress could annihilate!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Come on, I don't see you living in a cave!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: And I don't see you sunbathing at Chernobyl!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Just like old times.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Yeah.  Old times.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I want you to know that I really appreciate you helping me.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'm glad you came to me for help.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I feel very emotional right now.  A bit out of control.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Probably the caffeine.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Do you have something to bring me down?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: No problem.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Uh oh.  I remember that temper.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Daniel, I didn't hear you come down...

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What's wrong?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The nanobot... it's not here...

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: It's still inside me?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: How far can you stretch?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'm going to go out for a while.  I want to take the blood samples to a lab that has the equipment I need.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What did you want my hair for?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Something else I want to try.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I could go with you.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I think it would be better for me to go alone.  I'm sure Sim is looking for you.  Just sit tight.  I'll bring you back a pizza.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: No cheese.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I was hoping you were over that. Remember to keep drinking fluids.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: That's pretty good.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Getting used to it.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It's a crime fighting costume, what do you think?  It's underwear, so if you lose your clothes you'll still be decent.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: That's going to fit me?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Like a glove.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You made this out of my hair?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Sort of.  We used a process similar to the vulcanization of rubber and added bulk with a chain of chloroprene elastomers.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Did you go?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: On the counter.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Who is he?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: The head shrinker at the prison.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh no.  They're trying to blame you for the accident.  That means they must not have been able to control the replicators.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I can't go back to jail.  I gotta get out of here.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You're not going back to jail.  All we need to do is find the nanobot. Once the meltdown is under control, then we deal with Argon --

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I don't believe it.  You're here! Oh thank God.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You didn't think I could just leave you?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I didn't know what was going to happen.  I was just so worried something was going to happen to you.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What could happen?  I'm the plastic man, remember?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh no!  Argon!  We have to stop him before he uses the nanobot!  We have to get the nanobot!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Where is it?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Argon's private lab.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Let's go.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Run, Daniel!  Get out of here!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I'm not leaving without you, Susan!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You saved my life.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Did you think I could just leave you...?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Susie... I...

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You don't have to say anything, Daniel.  I'm a scientist.  I know what's happening.  I recognize the classic symptoms.  Dizziness, shortness of breath, sweating palms... I can feel my adrenals secreting, my parasympathetic nervous system quivering, the estradiol coursing through my entire body...

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What in the...?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh shit, the meltdown.  It's spread to the tower.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: We've got to get the nanobot.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It's too late.  Argon injected it.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You mean he's polymerized, like me?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: That means the nanobot is still inside him.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What would happen if I threw him into the core?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: The same thing I suppose.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Daniel, just forget Argon.  Let's get out of here.  We'll find another way to stop the waste.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: We don't have time to argue, Susan.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You're not going after Argon!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I have to!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Do the words 'hero fantasies' mean anything to you?  How about 'infantile dementia'?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: God, when we were in that store all I could think about was that one time, when we were in school, and you attacked that little kid who wanted some cereal.  Do you remember that?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I remember I was trying to help...

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: God, what a fight that was.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: We were different people then.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Do you suppose that was our problem? We met before our time?  I think that happens a lot.  People, events, planets all just circling each other waiting for that moment when everything clicks into place.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Things do change.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I guess they do.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: You!  I remember you!

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: I'm real touched.  Now get your Sunday's on.  We're going for a ride.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: What?  I'm not going anywhere!

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Oh yes you are!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: I get it.  You're the goon fetch boy.  The zookeeper Argon calls in when one of his guinea pigs gets loose.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Only this ain't no tranquilizer gun. Now let's go!

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Forget it, pissboy!  You tell Argon he can call my lawyer.

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: This is wonderfully accommodating of you all.  Now I won't have to come looking for you.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: You were looking for us?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: Yeah, I have something I've been meaning to give you.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Yeah, and what might that be?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: An ass-beating.  Would you like yours first, Mr. Sim?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: All the different ways that I could kill you.

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Oh yeah?

turns.speaker: SIM
turns.text: Maybe you're ready to find out if that hide of yours is bulletproof?

turns.speaker: O'BRIEN
turns.text: The question is, are you?
